61874601
>>61872964

61874605
>>61873185

61874655
>>61874587
Being a reserve currency gives you substantially more control than being a manufacturing giant, the US can literally print the oil price into the ground, as has been it's prerogative since the Ukraine war first started up in 2014 (speculatively to weaken the russian economy?) Anyways, if China had reserve currency then all other countries would need to stay at or exceed China's level of inflation in order to stay price-competitive and utilize the currency needed for global trade. This is assuming of course that the concept of a 'world reserve currency' continues to exist, but desu I see less and less reason for such a thing to exist as markets continue to accelerate their interactions and improve their pricing accuracy

61874731
>>61872971
>we simply won't import your products to our country

61874748
>>61874164
The reason for this is that they aren't as good at doing it so they are printing money wildly to brute force it all.

61874758
>>61874655
Oh I agree that being the reserve currency is the most enviable global position a country can have, and I understand why China would want it. I just wonder how, logistically, this shift would happen—how a country would make a smooth transition from manufacturing export king to a financial role that in many ways conflicts with exporting efficiently.

I am asking this out of ignorance: how would exchange rates function without a reserve currency to which they are pegged? Would a given currency just have its own exchange rate with every other currency? Seems maddening.

61874861
>>61874758
The exchange rates can still use USD as a reference point without USD being a reserve currency. Reserve currency means that if Canada ships natural gas to Vietnam, then Vietnam pays the Canadian company in USD instead of CAD or the vietnamese currency. Exchange rates would be calculated similarly to the way altcoins are measured against BTC a lot of the time, but to understand the real world value you need to reference BTC/USD. The reference point doesn't give the USD power, instead it's international trade conventions which compel most countries to buy and hold large stockpiles. That being said, if USD loses reserve status volatility would be very high compared to current day, so it may not even be a good idea to use it as a benchmark post-reserve status

61874896
>>61874861
Interesting, thanks for explaining.

However, wouldn’t being the currency to which other currencies are measured still encourage it to function as a reserve currency? For example, if the yuan is still measured against the dollar, wouldn’t it still set aside dollars to manipulate its strength? It seems to me that so long as a currency is the one to which all the others are measured, it will begin to function as a reserve currency, though perhaps to a lesser degree. Some power seems to be gained from being the reference point. Again, I could be wrong about this, I’m a little out of my element.

61874899
>>61874514
China hasn't relied on currency devaluation since the 1990s

61874905
>>61872964
I don't get why countries can't just take what policies they want.

China wants to subsidies industries? Fine.

USA wants to tariff those Chinese industries? Fine.

Both countries should just be able to do what they see fit without everyone freaking out about it. Will some people get negatively impacted? Probably, but that is the risk that comes from doing business.

61874924
>>61874896
It's literally just convention, you think business boomers want to spend mental energy on trading in more than two currencies? They don't give a fuck as long as the currency's worth approximately the same amount in between signing the contract and payment being issued

61874936
>>61874905
I do broadly agree, however if it looks like a country is going to debt-nuke the whole world you have to take some action at some point. The US is just as likely to shit the world economy as china is

61874965
>>61874899
Their currency is currently undervalued by roughly 16% and they actively manage its strength. How do you think they have such a ridiculous surplus? .

61874974
>>61874965
No they keep it tied to the dollar.

61875001
>>61874974
They have one of the most opaque central banks in the world. Nobody outside of China has any idea how they determine their exchange rate. It’s not hard to see the benefits they gain from keeping it low.

61875052
>>61875001
Trump admin:
>NO! NO! NO! Only WE'RE allowed to devalue our currency because WE need WAGESLAVES more than YOU! Y..you can't just print to build infrastructure!!! That's communist!!!!

61875074
>>61875052
I think the euros are more upset with china’s devaluation than America is. The guy in that article complaining is German.

They’re instantiating a levy on small goods in July to combat the yuan that refuses to budge.

61875077
>>61875001
How it's done? They just keep it tied to the dollar. What are you talking about?

61875121
>>61875077
It isn’t strictly tied to the dollar. It WAS before 2005, but now it’s a managed float system that is managed by the central bank. The dollar plays a big role, but it isn’t as if the yuan keeps strict pace with the dollar. They can (and do) manage its exchange rate. Exactly how they determine what the exchange rate should be is the opaque part. One way they manage the yuan’s value is by buying/selling dollars with their currency, and this is one reason why the keep so many dollars in reserve.

This is also why, earlier in the thread, I argued that the dollar’s role as a reference point for a currency can still cause it to be accumulated.

61875124
>>61872964
Sour fucking grapes. The Jews running the west are such idiots

>>61873887

Forgot to answer this part. We don't buy it in our portfolios, but we do help clients manage the risk associated with it. Some people are believers in crypto so we highlight the risks (volatility, no intrinsic value, etc) and then work with them to figure out how much of their overall investments is a prudent amount to put into that risk asset. I personally cap myself at 10% for both gold and crypto.

Crypto is actually considered speculation instead of investing by most managers. Kind of like commodities/gold/NFTs.

61874261
>>61873448
>its still not beating the stock market
It does in the 26-year backward looking period in the data array from the picture by 30bp. Instead of just pulling 7% out of your booty you could spend 10 seconds doing the present value calculation if you really wanted.


It's about 9.8% annualized if you go all the way back to '71 from now ($39-$5,000). That's definitely nothing to scoff at when constructing a portfolio and hedging equity markets considering the 0.1 correlation.

>That is insane volatility
Volatility is good in a portfolio of non-correlated assets that's rebalanced outside of tolerance bands.

>all that volatility it still doesn't match the market
Almost keeps up with it and doesn't move in the same direction, which is the idea. Non-correlated assets, rebalancing the volatility, and risk-return tradeoff are portfolio construction 101.

>>61874295
The software is pretty comprehensive and generally way deeper than just an excel sheet, but of course there's an industry spectrum of how deep/detailed the analysis goes by firm and by program.

Some is straight up basically a cash flows projection laid on top of a balance sheet (excel). The people that use this are shitty whole life insurance people.

It's the auxiliary software where the money is at right now it seems. AI that reads trusts using OCR and spits out a summary to help you find issues. Tax software. Stuff like that.

Our software for portfolio management (have used 3) is AWFUL though. That's a big gap for asset management imho.
